segments.text: Working on legacy code bases is proving
to be one of the harder challenges in AI
powered development in 2026. Your agents
can read every file in your project, but
they don't understand why you built
things the way that you did. The
reasoning behind your conventions, the
patterns that your team refined over the
years, the architectural decisions that
shape everything. None of that comes
through when an agent scans your code.
So, every time you prompt, you're
reexplaining, you're reteing, you're
reestablishing context that should
already be baked in. I created Agent OS
to fill that gap. It's a lightweight
system for defining and managing your
coding standards in AI powered
development. And today I'm releasing
version three. It's stripped down by 70%
yet it's more useful than ever for how
we actually build here in 2026. Now, if
you saw my last video on the channel
where I said cloud code is all you need,
I also promised a follow-up showing what
I actually want out of a utility
framework. This is that video. The
philosophy behind version 3 of Agent OS
is simple. Don't reinvent what the core
tools already do well. Strip away
everything that overlaps with Cloud
Code's native features and keep only
what fills the gaps that professionals
and teams actually care about. Now, if
you're new to the channel, I'm Brian
Castle. I help professional builders
stay ahead of the curve with AI first
development. And every Friday, I send my
builder briefing. That's a free 5minute
read. No hype, just my take on this
transition into building with AI. You
can get my next one by going to
buildermethods.com. Now, agent OS has
always been built around specdriven
development. The idea that we should
plan before we build, shape the work
first, and then let agents execute. So,
when I first released Agent OS back in
mid2025, the tooling wasn't quite there
yet. So, I created Agent OS to build in
scaffolding for writing specs and
breaking them into task lists and
orchestrating implementation. But since
then, cloud code and cursor and others
have evolved significantly. Plan mode is
now a first class feature and today's
frontier models are dramatically better
at maintaining context and executing
complex multi-step plans without losing
the thread. So the question became what
does agent OS actually need to do now if
anything? The answer is it should fill
the gaps that vanilla cloud code doesn't
address without stepping on the features
that it already handles well. So in the
new agent OS version 3 I reduced its
footprint by 70% and in doing so made it
significantly more useful. So let me
explain what stayed and what's new. So
agent OS was always built on the idea
that you define your standards first.
You know your conventions for how you
build things like our API responses use
this structure or our components follow
this naming convention. Standards are
kind of similar to what you might put in
your claw.md file, but agent OS gives
you a system to inject only what's
relevant and not load everything into
context every time. What's new in V3 is
that Agent OS now discovers and writes
your standards for you. So, you can run
a command, point it at an area of your
codebase, and it analyzes what's there,
looking for patterns that are unusual or
opinionated, you know, things that a new
developer or an agent wouldn't know
without being told. So, it interviews
you with targeted questions to capture
your reasoning behind what it found.
This is knowledge that used to exist in
between the lines of your code or in
your head, but now formalized and
accessible in a way that your agents can
actually use. Second, Asian OS gives you
enhanced spec shaping. So, plan mode is
now the industry standard for spec
driven development and is built right
into cloud code and cursor and most
major tools. So, Agent OS enhances that
by helping you shape your specs with
targeted questions that take your
standards and your product's mission
into account. Agent OS also saves your
plans into persistent spec folders,
something that cloud code doesn't do by
default. Third is profiles. So this lets
you maintain different sets of standards
for different project types. So maybe
you have a Laravel profile and a
marketing site profile and an internal
tools profile. Set them up once and then
choose the right one when you're
starting up a new project. And Agent OS
version 3 gives you a new way to sync
your standards from your current project
into a profile so that you can port them
into other projects later. Okay, let me
show you what this looks like in
practice. So, I'm going to use my
buildermethods.com codebase for the
demos that I'm going to show here. And
this is a Rails application uh including
the the front end as well as like the
members area for builder methods pro,
the videos library, our workshops. So,
I've been working on this site and the
backend app for a while now, and it's uh
it's a somewhat legacy codebase with
with some established patterns that are
just starting to be formally documented.
So, it's a perfect candidate for agent
OS. Now, I have already installed agent
OS on my system by following the uh
installation instructions. You know,
first you would clone the repo to your
home directory on your system. That's
your base installation. And then you
would install agent OS into each
individual project by using our project
install script. So I have already done
that in my uh builder methods project
here. And so that put this agent OS
folder into the project. And inside that
we've got a product folder. I've already
run the agent OS plan product command
which helped me establish my product
mission uh the road map and the tech
stack through this codebase. It also has
a specs folder. So, I've been using
previous versions of Agent OS to uh to
create these specs. And I'm going to
continue using that specs folder as I
move forward now with Agent OS version
3. And then we have the standards
folder. And this is where we document
our conventions and the knowledge behind
our codebase. And so I've already done
that here in the builder methods
codebase. And so I have this folder in
there called agent OS. And inside that
I've got a product folder. So this was
generated when I ran the agent OS plan
product command that helped me establish
the mission for the product, the road
map and the text stack for this
codebase. And I have some specs from the
previous versions of Agent OS in there.
I can continue to use this specs folder
going forward. And I have the standards
folder. This is where I'm documenting
those conventions and the the knowledge
behind my project. Now, if you've just
installed AgentOS into a project for the
first time, the first thing that you'll
probably want to do is run the plan
product command. Now, I've already done
that here, but again, that will uh
establish your your product's mission
and road map and tech stack. But the
other thing that you'll want to do early
and often throughout the life cycle of
your project is discovering and
documenting new standards from your
codebase. Now I'm going to do this in
cloud code but you can do this in any
agent cursor agent or any of the modern
tools these days. So I'm going to start
by running discover standards command.
And so what this is going to do is it's
going to look around my codebase and
start to identify some big focus areas
that we can then dive into and look for
some unique patterns that might be worth
documenting. So here it found a few big
focus areas like you know controllers,
models, views and components. I could go
with one of those or I can direct it
toward a specific area of my codebase.
Now I actually do want to create some
standards around the views and
components. That's something that I have
not yet documented in my standard. So
I'm going to go ahead and go with that
option. throughout agent OS. Now, we're
using the ask user question tool, which
is built into cloud code, which gives us
that really nice Q&A interface to ask us
these questions and proceed with these
workflows. Now, it's analyzing all of my
views and components, and what it's
specifically looking for are the areas
that appear to be unique or opinionated
and follow a repeatable pattern. Those
are the types of things that we want to
actually document into standards. We
don't necessarily just want to write
standards that teach agents how to code
in a conventional way because agents
already do that. So agent OS is going to
help to find those unique knowledge in
your codebase. All right, so it found
about five unique patterns in my views
and components and all of these sound
pretty accurate to how the codebase is
structured. So um you know I could

but I'm going to go with the first
option which is yeah let's create
standards for all of them. And so
instead of rushing into documenting
these standards and making some
assumptions, the agent is actually going
to interview me to understand the
reasoning behind why things were
designed or architected a certain way.
You know, it's asking me like, what
problem does this particular pattern
solve? And these are really good
strategic and design questions that we
want to bake into the knowledge that's
in our system here. And again, I can use
the uh suggested answers or I can uh
give a little bit more color to my
reasoning and and design patterns here.
So, the way that it works is it asks one
or two questions about each new
standard. Then it goes ahead and drafts
that standard. And the key here is to
keep the standards really concise. We
don't want to eat up too much of the
context window when we pull them into
the context. So, it's going to show us
the draft and then I can approve it or
skip it or give it some feedback. I'll
approve this one. So, it's going to go
ahead and write it up and save it. And
now we're moving right along into the
next standard that it identified. So,
it's going to ask me a question. And I
gave it a quick confirmation. And now
it's going to go ahead and write it up.
Looks good. Create it. So, I'm going to
have it go through the rest of these
now. And this is a cycle that you can
repeat periodically throughout the life
cycle of your product as it evolves, as
the codebase grows. And uh you know,
especially after you've added a whole
new section to your to your codebase,
it's probably a good time to go ahead
and discover any new standards that may
have surfaced. Now, when you get to the
end of the process of discovering and
writing up new standards, Asian OS will
index your standards. And it does that
inside your standards folder, you have
an index.yaml file. So, this is a list
of each of the individual uh standards
files uh within the folder that they
live in. And each standards file gets a
oneline simple description. And so the
reason we do it this way, of course, is
so that uh the agent doesn't need to
read the entire contents of every single
standard file, which would read all of
that content into the context window
every single time. This enables it to
identify which standards are available
just by reading these descriptions. And
then it lets you choose or it will
suggest standards to inject. This is
very similar to the way that Claude
skills work. skills also are not read
into uh the context by default and the
agent can identify the skills uh based
on their descriptions. In fact, agent OS
can also help you surface available
skills to inject along with your agent
OS standards. So real quick, you know,
like the difference between a a cloud
skill and an agent OS standard. A skill
is more of a processoriented task that
you want to invoke and then run uh the
same way every time. Whereas the
standards that you would document with
agent OS are again, you know,
conventions and uh best practices and
your opinions and your design patterns
that it might use and apply in different
ways depending on the task. So, I'm
going to finish up that last process of
uh indexing those new standards that
we've just added to our list. And by the
way, uh if you ever need to just index

another uh tool that's available inside
uh cloud code. And so, now that we have
a a pretty good set of standards all
documented and and set up in my agent OS

you can inject standards when you're

to create a new Claude skill. In fact,

I'm going to use dictation here. Let's

fullText: Working on legacy code bases is proving to be one of the harder challenges in AI powered development in 2026. Your agents can read every file in your project, but they don't understand why you built things the way that you did. The reasoning behind your conventions, the patterns that your team refined over the years, the architectural decisions that shape everything. None of that comes through when an agent scans your code. So, every time you prompt, you're reexplaining, you're reteing, you're reestablishing context that should already be baked in. I created Agent OS to fill that gap. It's a lightweight system for defining and managing your coding standards in AI powered development. And today I'm releasing version three. It's stripped down by 70% yet it's more useful than ever for how we actually build here in 2026. Now, if you saw my last video on the channel where I said cloud code is all you need, I also promised a follow-up showing what I actually want out of a utility framework. This is that video. The philosophy behind version 3 of Agent OS is simple. Don't reinvent what the core tools already do well. Strip away everything that overlaps with Cloud Code's native features and keep only what fills the gaps that professionals and teams actually care about. Now, if you're new to the channel, I'm Brian Castle. I help professional builders stay ahead of the curve with AI first development. And every Friday, I send my builder briefing. That's a free 5minute read. No hype, just my take on this transition into building with AI. You can get my next one by going to buildermethods.com. Now, agent OS has always been built around specdriven development. The idea that we should plan before we build, shape the work first, and then let agents execute. So, when I first released Agent OS back in mid2025, the tooling wasn't quite there yet. So, I created Agent OS to build in scaffolding for writing specs and breaking them into task lists and orchestrating implementation. But since then, cloud code and cursor and others have evolved significantly. Plan mode is now a first class feature and today's frontier models are dramatically better at maintaining context and executing complex multi-step plans without losing the thread. So the question became what does agent OS actually need to do now if anything? The answer is it should fill the gaps that vanilla cloud code doesn't address without stepping on the features that it already handles well. So in the new agent OS version 3 I reduced its footprint by 70% and in doing so made it significantly more useful. So let me explain what stayed and what's new. So agent OS was always built on the idea that you define your standards first. You know your conventions for how you build things like our API responses use this structure or our components follow this naming convention. Standards are kind of similar to what you might put in your claw.md file, but agent OS gives you a system to inject only what's relevant and not load everything into context every time. What's new in V3 is that Agent OS now discovers and writes your standards for you. So, you can run a command, point it at an area of your codebase, and it analyzes what's there, looking for patterns that are unusual or opinionated, you know, things that a new developer or an agent wouldn't know without being told. So, it interviews you with targeted questions to capture your reasoning behind what it found. This is knowledge that used to exist in between the lines of your code or in your head, but now formalized and accessible in a way that your agents can actually use. Second, Asian OS gives you enhanced spec shaping. So, plan mode is now the industry standard for spec driven development and is built right into cloud code and cursor and most major tools. So, Agent OS enhances that by helping you shape your specs with targeted questions that take your standards and your product's mission into account. Agent OS also saves your plans into persistent spec folders, something that cloud code doesn't do by default. Third is profiles. So this lets you maintain different sets of standards for different project types. So maybe you have a Laravel profile and a marketing site profile and an internal tools profile. Set them up once and then choose the right one when you're starting up a new project. And Agent OS version 3 gives you a new way to sync your standards from your current project into a profile so that you can port them into other projects later. Okay, let me show you what this looks like in practice. So, I'm going to use my buildermethods.com codebase for the demos that I'm going to show here. And this is a Rails application uh including the the front end as well as like the members area for builder methods pro, the videos library, our workshops. So, I've been working on this site and the backend app for a while now, and it's uh it's a somewhat legacy codebase with with some established patterns that are just starting to be formally documented. So, it's a perfect candidate for agent OS. Now, I have already installed agent OS on my system by following the uh installation instructions. You know, first you would clone the repo to your home directory on your system. That's your base installation. And then you would install agent OS into each individual project by using our project install script. So I have already done that in my uh builder methods project here. And so that put this agent OS folder into the project. And inside that we've got a product folder. I've already run the agent OS plan product command which helped me establish my product mission uh the road map and the tech stack through this codebase. It also has a specs folder.
